Banach spaces, Hahn-Banach

Let V1V_1V1​ be a finite-dimensional subspace of the Banach space VVV. Show that there exists a continuous projection P ⁣:V→V1\func{P}{V}{V_1}P:V→V1​, i.e., a continuous linear map P ⁣:V→V\func{P}{V}{V}P:V→V such that P2=PP^2 = PP2=P and the range of PPP is equal to V1V_1V1​.
Solution.

Let {x1,…,xn}\set{x_1, \ldots, x_n}{x1​,…,xn​} be a basis for V1V_1V1​. Normalizing, we may assume that ∥xi∥=1\norm{x_i} = 1∥xi​∥=1 for each iii. We have a canonical isomorphism φ ⁣:V1→Rn\func{\phi}{V_1}{\R^n}φ:V1​→Rn, via

∑i=1ncixi↦∑i=1nciei\sum_{i=1}^n c_ix_i \mapsto \sum_{i=1}^n c_ie_ii=1∑n​ci​xi​↦i=1∑n​ci​ei​

In Rn\R^nRn, we have the projection map πi ⁣:Rn→R\func{\pi_i}{\R^n}{\R}πi​:Rn→R onto the iii-th component, and so αi ⁣:V1→R\func{\alpha_i}{V_1}{\R}αi​:V1​→R given by αi=πi∘φ\alpha_i = \pi_i \circ \phiαi​=πi​∘φ is a bounded linear functional on V1V_1V1​. By Hahn-Banach, they all admit extensions to αi∈V∗\alpha_i \in V^*αi​∈V∗, so we define

P(x)=∑i=1nαi(x)xi.P\p{x} = \sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i\p{x} x_i.P(x)=i=1∑n​αi​(x)xi​.

PPP is linear by construction and is continuous since

∥P(x)−P(y)∥≤(∑i=1n∥αi∥)∥x−y∥,\norm{P\p{x} - P\p{y}} \leq \p{\sum_{i=1}^n \norm{\alpha_i}}\norm{x - y},∥P(x)−P(y)∥≤(i=1∑n​∥αi​∥)∥x−y∥,

and for any x∈V1x \in V_1x∈V1​,

P(x)=∑i=1nαi(x)xi=xP\p{x} = \sum_{i=1}^n \alpha_i\p{x}x_i = xP(x)=i=1∑n​αi​(x)xi​=x

by construction. Thus, P2=PP^2 = PP2=P and im⁡P=V1\im{P} = V_1imP=V1​, which completes the proof.
